statements.name: PROC OPTEX
statements.description: The OPTEX procedure searches for optimal experimental designs. You specify a set of candidate design points and a linear model, and the procedure chooses points so that the terms in the model can be estimated as efficiently as possible.

arguments.name: CLASSPARAM
arguments.description: Specifies that a table should be displayed summarizing the parameterization of classification variables in the model for the design.

arguments.name: CODING=
arguments.description: Specifies which type of coding to use for modeling effects in the design.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses coding of effects

arguments.name: STATIC
arguments.description: Specifies that the values of all effects are to be coded to have maximum and minimum values of +1 and -1, respectively.

arguments.name: ORTH
arguments.description: Specifies orthogonal coding with respect to the points in the candidate data set.

arguments.name: ORTHCAN
arguments.description: Specifies orthogonal coding with respect to the points in the candidate data set.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the input SAS data set that contains the candidate points for the design.

arguments.name: EPSILON=
arguments.description: Specifies the smallest value ε that is considered to be nonzero for determining when the search is no longer yielding an improved design and when the information matrix for the design is singular. By default, ε = 0.00001.

arguments.name: NAMELEN=
arguments.description: Specifies the length of effect names in tables and output data sets to be n characters long, where n is a value between 20 and 200 characters. The default length is 20 characters.

arguments.name: NOCODE
arguments.description: Suppresses the coding of effects in the model for the design. This option is equivalent to CODING=NONE.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses all output. This is useful when you only want the final design to be saved in a data set.

arguments.name: SEED=
arguments.description: Specifies an integer used to start the pseudo-random number generator for initialization.

arguments.name: STATUS=
arguments.description: Specifies that the status of the search be checked at the given level, where status-level is an integer between 1 and 4, inclusive.
Checks status after each design search; the number of searches specified by the NITER= option.
Checks status after each search loop.
Checks status after each internal search loop.
Checks status after each extra internal search loop for METHOD=M_FEDOROV.

statements.name: BLOCKS
statements.description: You use the BLOCKS statement to find a D-optimal design in the presence of fixed covariates (for example, blocks) or covariance.

arguments.name: INIT=
arguments.description: Specifies that the starting design is to be constructed by selecting candidates at random without replacement.

arguments.name: ITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of times to repeat the search from different initial designs.

arguments.name: KEEP=
arguments.description: Specifies that only the best m designs are to be retained. The value m must be less than or equal to the value n of the ITER= option.

arguments.name: NOEXCHANGE
arguments.description: Suppresses the part of the optimal blocking algorithm that exchanges treatment design points for candidate treatment points.

arguments.name: STRUCTURE=
arguments.description: Specifies a block design with b blocks of size k.

arguments.name: VAR=
arguments.description: Names the variables in the data set (specified in the COVAR= option) that contain the columns of the covariance matrix for the runs.

arguments.name: COVAR=
arguments.description: Specifies a data set to use in providing a general covariance matrix for the runs.

arguments.name: DESIGN=
arguments.description: Specifies a data set to use in providing a general covariate model.

statements.name: CLASS
statements.description: You use the CLASS statement to identify classification (qualitative) variables, which are factors that separate the observations into groups.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Reverses the sorting order of the classification variable.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: Specifies the sorting order for the levels of classification variables.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Orders values according to their order in the input data set.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: Orders values by their ascending formatted values. This order depends on your operating environment.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Orders values by descending frequency count so that levels with the most observations are listed first.

arguments.name: INTERNAL
arguments.description: Orders values by their unformatted values, which yields the same order as PROC SORT. This order depends on your operating environment.

arguments.name: PARAM=
arguments.description: Specifies the parameterization method for the classification variable or variables.
arguments.help: PARAM=EFFECT | POLYNOMIAL|POLY | REFERENCE|REF | ORDINAL|ORD | ORTHEFFECT | ORTHPOLY | ORTHREF | ORTHORDINAL

arguments.name: EFFECT
arguments.description: Specifies effect coding.

arguments.name: POLYNOMIAL
arguments.description: Specifies polynomial coding.

arguments.name: REFERENCE
arguments.description: Specifies reference cell coding.

arguments.name: ORDINAL
arguments.description: Specifies ordinal, or 'thermometer' coding.

arguments.name: ORTHEFFECT
arguments.description: Specifies orthogonal effect coding.

arguments.name: ORTHPOLY
arguments.description: Specifies orthogonal effect coding.

arguments.name: ORTHREF
arguments.description: Specifies orthogonal reference cell coding.

arguments.name: ORTHORDINAL
arguments.description: Specifies orthogonal ordinal coding.

arguments.name: REF=
arguments.description: Specifies the reference level for PARAM=EFFECT, or PARAM=REFERENCE.

arguments.name: <’level’>
arguments.description: For an individual (but not a global) variable REF= option, you can specify the level of the variable to use as the reference level. Replace 'level' with an actual value, enclosed in quotes.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: For a global or individual variable REF= option, this designates the first ordered level as reference.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: For a global or individual variable REF= option, this designates the last ordered level as reference.

arguments.name: TRUNCATE
arguments.description: Specifies that class levels should be determined by using only up to the first 16 characters of the formatted values of CLASS variables.

statements.name: EXAMINE
statements.description: You use the EXAMINE statement to display the characteristics of a selected design.

arguments.name: DESIGN
arguments.description: Lists the actual points in the selected design.

arguments.name: INFORMATION
arguments.description: Lists the information matrix X'X for the selected design.

arguments.name: NUMBER=
arguments.description: Selects a design to examine by specifying its design-number.

arguments.name: VARIANCE
arguments.description: Lists the variance matrix (X'X)⁻¹ for the parameter estimates for the selected design.

statements.name: GENERATE
statements.description: You use the GENERATE statement to customize the search for a design.

arguments.name: AUGMENT=
arguments.description: Specifies a data set that contains a design to be augmented---in other words, a set of points that must be contained in the design generated.

arguments.name: CRITERION=
arguments.description: Specifies the optimality criterion used in the search.

arguments.name: D
arguments.description: Specifies D-optimality.

arguments.name: A
arguments.description: Specifies A-optimality.

arguments.name: U
arguments.description: Specifies U-optimality.

arguments.name: S
arguments.description: Specifies S-optimality.

arguments.name: INITDESIGN=
arguments.description: Specifies a method for obtaining an initial design for the search procedure.

arguments.name: SEQUENTIAL
arguments.description: Specifies an initial design chosen by a sequential search.

arguments.name: RANDOM
arguments.description: Specifies a completely random initial design.

arguments.name: PARTIAL
arguments.description: Syntax: PARTIAL<(m)> Specifies an initial design by using a mixture of RANDOM and SEQUENTIAL methods. A small number nr of points for the initial design are chosen at random from the candidates, and the rest of the design points are chosen by a sequential search. You can specify the optional integer n to modify the selection of nr.

arguments.name: SAS-data-set
arguments.description: Specifies a data set that holds the initial design.

arguments.name: ITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the number n of searches to make. Because local optima are common in difficult search problems, it is often a good idea to make several tries for the optimal design with a random or partially random method of initialization (see the INITDESIGN= option). By default, n = 10. The n designs found are sorted by their respective efficiencies according to the current optimality criterion (see the CRITERION=option.) The most efficient design is assigned a design-number of 1, the second most efficient design is assigned a design-number of 2, and so on. You can then use the design-number in the EXAMINE and OUTPUT statements to display the characteristics of a design or to save a design in a data set.

arguments.name: KEEP=
arguments.description: Specifies that only the best m designs are to be retained. The value m must be less than or equal to the value n of the ITER= option. By default m=n, so that all iterations are kept. This option is useful when you want to make many searches to overcome the problem of local optima but are interested only in the results of the best m designs.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the procedure used to search for the optimal design.

arguments.name: DETMAX
arguments.description: Syntax: DETMAX<(level)> The optional level gives the maximum excursion level for the search, where level is an integer greater than or equal to 1.

arguments.name: EXCHANGE
arguments.description: Syntax: EXCHANGE<(k)> The optional k specifies the k-exchange search method of Johnson and Nachtsheim (1983), which generalizes the modified Fedorov search algorithm of Cook and Nachtsheim (1980). Enclose the value of k in parentheses immediately following the word EXCHANGE.

arguments.name: FEDOROV
arguments.description: Fedorov search algorithm

arguments.name: M_FEDOROV
arguments.description: Modified Fedorov search algorithm

arguments.name: SEQUENTIAL
arguments.description: Sequential search algorithm

arguments.name: N=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of points in the final design. The default design size is 10 + p, where p is the number of parameters in the model.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: Specifies the number of points in the final design.

arguments.name: SATURATED
arguments.description: Specifies to search for a design with the same number of points as there are parameters in the model.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: You use the ID statement to name the variables in the DATA= data set that are not involved in the model but are to be transferred from the input data set to the output data set.

statements.name: MODEL
statements.description: You use the MODEL statement to specify the independent effects used to model data that are to be collected with the design that is being constructed.

arguments.name: NOINT
arguments.description: Excludes the intercept parameter from the model.

arguments.name: PRIOR=
arguments.description: Specifies prior precision values corresponding to groups of effects in the model. Groups of effects in the MODEL statement with the same prior precision must be separated by commas. Then use the PRIOR= option, listing as many prior precision values as there are groups of effects.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: You use the OUTPUT statement to save a design in an output data set.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Gives a name for the output data set. The OUT= data set is required in the OUTPUT statement.

arguments.name: BLOCKNAME=
arguments.description: Specifies the name to be given to the blocking variable in the output data set. The default name is BLOCK.

arguments.name: NUMBER=
arguments.description: Selects a design to output by specifying its design-number. Designs are ordered by the value of the efficiency criterion that is being optimized.

arguments.name: DBEST
arguments.description: Selects the design that has the highest D-efficiency value.

arguments.name: ABEST
arguments.description: Selects the design that has the highest A-efficiency value.

arguments.name: GBEST
arguments.description: Selects the design that has the highest G-efficiency value.

arguments.name: VBEST
arguments.description: Selects the design that has the minimum average standard error for prediction.
